courseTitle: Topics in Education
courseDescription: Explores contemporary problems and trends in education. Emphasis is placed upon topics related to curriculum, instructional strategies, and evaluation.

courseTitle: Foundations and Introduction to Assessment of Education
courseDescription: Introduces the historical, philosophical, and sociological foundations and contemporary issues of American public education.  Includes the use and analysis of assessment data and the construction and interpretation of assessments.  Students are expected independently to register for and take the Praxis Core examination while enrolled in this course.  Students in PreK-6 programs will complete a 15 hour observation/participation experience in a primary setting (preK-3) and a 15 hour observation/participation experience in an upper elementary (4-6) setting; students in 6-12 or 6-8 programs will complete a 30 hour observation/participation experience in an appropriate 6-12 setting.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Observation and participation in educational settings
Interaction with students and teachers in PreK-6 and 6-12 programs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Historical, philosophical, and sociological analysis of American public education
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time and responsibilities during observation/participation experiences

courseTitle: Perspectives on the Young Child and the Family
courseDescription: This course examines the familial lives of young children (Birth through Grade 3) and supports understandings of working with parents and families in early childhood settings. Family systems theory provides the basis for study and guides understandings of contemporary family structures. The stages of the family life cycle are explored; principles of healthy family functioning are emphasized to promote healthy growth for children.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with stages of family life cycle
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to work with parents and families in early childhood settings
Empathy towards familial lives of young children
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing principles of healthy family functioning
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing relationships in early childhood settings
Leading initiatives for child growth and family well-being

courseTitle: Socio-Cultural Perspectives in Education
courseDescription: This course will utilize a framework of sociocultural theory situated within culturally sustaining pedagogical practices to explore issues related to race, ethnicity, class, gender, sexuality, religion, and language use. Students will learn to create an educational environment that values diversity and employs research-based strategies. The course also examines and evaluates multicultural and global literature that explores issues of diversity.
Technical and Digital Skills: Usage of multicultural and global literature
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication and engagement with diverse groups
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation and analysis of multicultural and global literature
Issues identification related to race, ethnicity, class, gender, sexuality, religion, and language use
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Creation of an educational environment that values diversity
Implementation of culturally sustaining pedagogical practices

courseTitle: Observation and Assessment in Early Childhood
courseDescription: This course examines the observation/assessment techniques used in early childhood classrooms as part of a coordinated approach to implement a reflective, high quality early childhood classroom. The purpose of this course is to introduce and support students’ development of skills related to the observation and interpretation of children’s daily activities and behaviors. This course includes a 20-hour practicum.
Technical and Digital Skills: Observation techniques in early childhood classrooms
Interpretation of children's daily activities and behaviors
Assessment techniques in early childhood classrooms
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinated approach to implement reflective classrooms

courseTitle: The Arts in Early Childhood and Elementary Education
courseDescription: An exploration of principles, methods, and materials for teaching the arts to young children. Emphasis is on making, interpreting, and designing meaningful art experiences for young children pre-K-grade 3. Students will be asked to participate in activities associated with making and viewing art, as well as design comprehensive learning experiences that encourage children to make and respond to art through conversation, storytelling, play, dramatics, movement, music, and art making.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding principles and methods of teaching arts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Encouraging children to respond to art
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting art teaching methods to different age groups
Developing strategies to encourage child engagement

courseTitle: Literature for Young Children
courseDescription: This course is designed to provide students with approaches for introducing young children to literature and reading. The course will examine a variety of children's literature genres and explore relationships between language, theory, politics, ideology and print material. Students will design activities that extend children’s literacy experiences, reading enjoyment, writing capabilities, and incorporate cultural and linguistic diversity in social studies, math, science, and the arts.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of political and ideological themes in literature
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of relationships between language, theory, politics, ideology and print material
Designing activities to extend children’s literacy experiences
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Design and implementation of literacy-related activities
Leadership in promoting cultural and linguistic diversity

courseTitle: Integrated Methods & Curriculum in Early Childhood Ed: Birth-Pre-K
courseDescription: This course examines the development of curriculum and instructional practices for children in infant, toddler, and preschool settings. The course will focus on the principles and methods of understanding and working with the young child across the content areas of early mathematics, science, literacy, social studies, and the arts. Course includes a 40 hour practicum placement in an early care classroom.
Technical and Digital Skills: Curriculum development for early childhood education
Instructional practices for infants, toddlers, and preschoolers
Understanding and implementing early mathematics, science, literacy, social studies, and the arts curriculums
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating effectively in an early childhood education setting
Building relationships with children in an early care classroom
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding the needs and behaviours of young children
Adapting curriculum and instructional practices to individual child needs
Evaluating the effectiveness of early childhood education programs

courseTitle: Classroom Management and Discipline
courseDescription: Examines theories, research, and practices involved in classroom management, motivation, and discipline.  Explores techniques for organizing and arranging classroom environments that are most conducive to learning.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of classroom management theories and practices
Application of research in classroom organization and arrangement
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading and managing a classroom effectively

courseTitle: Topics in Education
courseDescription: Explores contemporary problems and trends in education.  Emphasis is placed upon topics related to curriculum, instructional strategies, and evaluation.

courseTitle: Reading and Writing in Content Areas
courseDescription: This course examines and promotes literacy development in all content areas, including the development and use of disciplinary comprehension and writing/production skills. Students will explore and consider a repertoire of questioning strategies, and strategies in literal, interpretive, critical, analytical, and evaluative comprehension across the curriculum, grades 6-12.
Technical and Digital Skills: Development and use of disciplinary comprehension skills
Writing and production skills in various content areas
Application of literal, interpretive, critical, analytical, and evaluative comprehension strategies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex concepts clearly
Use of questioning strategies to facilitate understanding
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving through the use of comprehension strategies
Evaluative comprehension to assess the quality and relevance of information
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and managing information from various content areas

courseTitle: Introduction to Literacy, Linguistics and Practice in the Classroom
courseDescription: This course will provide students with an overview of the foundations of theory and best practices in literacy instruction. Emphasis is placed on Science of Reading (SOR), including phonemic awareness, phonics, developing decoding foundational skills, vocabulary, fluency, and comprehension. This course adopts an approach rooted in culturally sustaining pedagogy, aiming to create a learning environment that promotes equity and engagement for all learners. The course will support student's professional preparation as a teacher who promotes the success of all students through the implementation of excellent literacy instruction.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Promoting equity and engagement in classroom
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and application of literacy instruction best practices
Improving literacy and comprehension among students

courseTitle: PK-12 Instructional Technology
courseDescription: Classroom technology and learning strategies are explored through authentic technology and writing activities. This writing intensive (W) course uses contemporary productivity tools and Internet resources to develop and evaluate progressive instructional techniques and K-12 standards-based curriculum materials, which have changed as a result of the development and integration of technology in the classroom.
Technical and Digital Skills: Development and evaluation of K-12 standards-based curriculum materials through technology
Integration of technology in the classroom
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting and explaining complex concepts in a simple manner
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessing the impact of technology integration on learning strategies
Adapting to changes in curriculum due to technology integration
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and organizing technology-based learning activities
Leading the implementation of technology in the classroom
Coordinating with peers for curriculum development

courseTitle: Developing Instructional Strategies PreK-6: Language Arts
courseDescription: Following a theory into practice philosophy, students explore, develop, and use instructional strategies, materials, technologies, and activities to promote children's development of attitudes, behaviors, and concepts in language arts in grades PreK-6 in support of NCTE national instructional standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Promoting positive attitudes and behaviors in students
Communicating effectively with children in PreK-6
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting strategies to meet NCTE instructional standards
Aligning activities with Virginia Standards of Learning
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a language arts classroom in a PreK-6 setting

courseTitle: Developing Instructional Strategies PreK-6: Social Studies
courseDescription: Following a theory into practice philosophy, students explore, develop, and use instructional strategies, materials, technologies, and activities to promote children's development of attitudes, behaviors, and concepts in social studies in grades PreK-6 in support of NCSS national instructional standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and applying NCSS national instructional standards
Understanding and applying Virginia Standards of Learning
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing children's development and learning needs
Adapting instructional strategies to suit individual learning needs
Evaluating the effectiveness of instructional strategies

courseTitle: Developing Instructional Strategies for Teaching in the Middle/High School: English
courseDescription: Following a theory/research-into-practice philosophy, students explore, develop, and use instructional strategies, materials, technologies, and activities to promote the development of attitudes, behaviors, and concepts in English, grades 6-12, informed by national instructional standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning; 35 hours of teaching practicum required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and implementing Virginia Standards of Learning
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Promoting development of attitudes and behaviors
Effective communication in an educational setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting and developing materials for instruction
Evaluating the effectiveness of instructional strategies

courseTitle: Developing Instructional Strategies for Teaching in Middle/High School: Math and Science
courseDescription: This science and mathematics course will provide methods for teaching diverse learners through culturally sustaining pedagogy, inquiry-oriented, and problem solving strategies using technology and engineering design principles. Students in this course take a required practicum (35 hours) in a secondary science or mathematics classroom to complete assigned content-focused activities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of mathematics and science content
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing educational situations to apply appropriate teaching methods
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a secondary science or mathematics classroom

courseTitle: Developing Instructional Strategies for Teaching in the Middle/High School: Social Studies
courseDescription: Following a theory/research-into-practice philosophy, students explore, develop, and use instructional strategies, materials, technologies, and activities to promote the development of attitudes, behaviors, and concepts in social studies, grades 6-12, informed by national instructional standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning; 35 hours of teaching practicum required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of the Virginia Standards of Learning
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Promotion of attitudes and behaviors in students
Effective communication of social studies concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of theory and research into practice
Adjustment of teaching strategies based on student progress

courseTitle: Language Acquisition and Reading for Students with Diverse Learning Needs
courseDescription: This course provides an overview of normal language development and language disorders which impact the acquisition of language based curriculum skills such as listening, speaking, reading, and written expression.  Emphasis is on instructional techniques to assist students with diverse learning needs to achieve reading and comprehension skills.  Effective reading strategies and curricula for individuals with disabilities will also be reviewed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of language development and disorders
Implementing effective reading strategies and curricula for individuals with disabilities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Adapting communication techniques to suit diverse learning needs
Expressing complex language concepts in understandable terms
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying language disorders impacting curriculum skills
Analyzing the effectiveness of instructional techniques
Evaluating the success of reading strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing tailored language and reading lessons
Leading diverse learners towards achieving reading and comprehension skills

courseTitle: Foundations and Contemporary Issues in Early Childhood Education
courseDescription: This course addresses current issues related to children and families in early childhood settings.  Contemporary research on pedagogical and formative assessment practices related to the education of young children will be discussed through critical exploration. This course will also have an associated 40 hour practicum (20 hours in an infant or toddler classroom and 20 hours in a preschool age classroom).
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of current issues in early childhood education
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in early childhood education settings

courseTitle: Integrating Instruction Across the Curriculum PreK-6
courseDescription: Following a theory into practice philosophy and building on the instructional strategies for specific disciplines, students explore, develop, and use advanced instructional materials, technologies, and activities to promote interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary instruction across the curriculum in grades PreK-6 in support of national standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning. The field experience component (40 hours) includes participation in prek-3 and 4th-6th grade classrooms in an accredited public or non-public school, per program requirement.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborative planning and implementation of curriculum
Building relationships with students and staff in an academic setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and aligning instruction with national standards
Aligning instruction with the Virginia Standards of Learning
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing field experience components and classroom participation

courseTitle: Classroom Management and Practice PreK-3; PreK-6
courseDescription: Course prepares prospective PreK-3 and PreK-6 teachers to provide instruction and management addressing the intellectual, physical, emotional and social needs of PreK-6 learners founded in empirically based practice.  The field based component (70 hours) includes participation in PreK-3 and 4th-6th grade classrooms in an accredited public or non-public school.  Students in the Prek-3 program are required to complete 35 hours in the Children's Learning and Research Center. Attendance at seminars and debriefing sessions is required.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Participation and engagement in seminars and debriefing sessions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Addressing various needs of PreK-6 learners
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in public or non-public school environments

courseTitle: Multicultural Young Adult Literature in Schools
courseDescription: This course will explore the reading and teaching of diverse young adult literature. Topics addressed include ideas about adolescents and their learning practices; characteristics of young adult literature and literary criticism; analysis of texts from a range of young adult genres; methods for teaching young adult literature; and lesson and unit design.
Technical and Digital Skills: Teaching methods for young adult literature
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and interpretation of diverse literature
Communicating complex ideas about adolescents and their learning practices
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing texts from a range of young adult genres
Evaluating characteristics of young adult literature

courseTitle: Seminar in Teacher Education
courseDescription: Explores issues, problems, concerns, and processes related to teaching and to entering the profession of teaching.  Passing scores on Elementary Education Multiple Subjects Assessment in licensure content area, passing scores on the Virginia Communication and Literacy Assessment (VCLA), and where appropriate passing scores on  Reading for Virginia Educators are required to pass this course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of Elementary Education Multiple Subjects Assessment
Understanding of Virginia Communication and Literacy Assessment
Understanding of Reading for Virginia Educators
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of teaching processes and methods
Identification and addressing of teaching-related issues

courseTitle: Teacher Candidate Internship
courseDescription: Internship in school.  Available for pass/fail grading only.

courseTitle: Student Teaching for Special Endorsement
courseDescription: Internship in school.  Available for pass/fail grading only.

courseTitle: Teacher Candidate Internship for Early Childhood Education
courseDescription: Field-based 14-week experiences in the early childhood setting that include a minimum of 150 hours of direct instruction. The teacher candidate internship is the culminating experience of all teacher education programs. This experience is a crucial part of a teacher candidate’s preparation to becoming a professional educator.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in an early childhood setting

courseTitle: Teacher Candidate Internship - Elementary Education
courseDescription: Five days per week for 14 weeks. Available for pass/fail grading only. Provides practice in teaching in grades PK-6 and in analyzing teaching approaches and behaviors. Examines instructional problems and concerns.

courseTitle: The Child and the Family: PreK-3
courseDescription: This course examines the familial lives of young children (Birth through Grade 3) and supports understandings of working with parents and families in early childhood. Family systems theory provides the basis for study and guides understandings of contemporary family structures. The stages of the family life cycle are explored; principles of healthy family functioning are emphasized to promote healthy growth for children.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of stages of the family life cycle
Understanding of principles of healthy family functioning
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication with families from various structures
Empathy and understanding towards different family dynamics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing different family structures and their impact on child development
Applying family systems theory to real-life family situations
Promoting healthy growth in diverse family environments
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Guiding families through stages of the family life cycle
Promoting principles of healthy family functioning
Leading discussions and initiatives in early childhood education settings

courseTitle: Integrating Instruction: Mathematics and Science Across the Early Childhood Curriculum
courseDescription: This course emphasizes the development of young children's problem solving skills, strategies, and abilities and the promotion of active science and math explorations within early childhood classrooms. Multiple perspectives and approaches to planning, teaching, and assessing science and mathematics in the early childhood classroom are explored and practiced. This course includes a 40 hour practicum experience in an early childhood classroom.
Technical and Digital Skills: Development of young children's problem-solving skills
Promotion of active science and math explorations
Planning of science and mathematics curriculum
Teaching methodologies for science and math
Assessing science and mathematics comprehension in early childhood
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating complex mathematical and scientific concepts in an early childhood setting
Effective communication within an early childhood classroom
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessing the effectiveness of science and math explorations
Designing and implementing problem-solving exercises for young children
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and planning for early childhood classroom activities
Managing a 40-hour practicum experience in an early childhood classroom

courseTitle: Integrating Literacy and Social Studies Across the PreK - 3 Curriculum
courseDescription: This course emphasizes the development of young children's multiple literacies and the promotion of active literacy and social studies explorations within early childhood classrooms.  Multiple perspectives and approaches to planning, teaching, and assessing literacy and social studies in the early childhood classroom are explored and practiced. This course includes a 40 hour practicum experience in an early childhood classroom.
Technical and Digital Skills: Planning and teaching literacy and social studies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Promotion of active literacy and social studies explorations
Effective communication in the early childhood classroom
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in literacy and social studies teaching
Analysis of student performance in literacy and social studies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and leading literacy and social studies explorations
Leading a 40 hour practicum experience in an early childhood classroom

courseTitle: Topics in Education
courseDescription: Explores contemporary problems and trends in education.  Emphasis is placed upon topics related to curriculum, instructional strategies, and evaluation.

courseTitle: Topics in Education
courseDescription: Cannot be applied to a Master of Science in Education degree in the Department of Teaching and Learning.  Explores contemporary problems and trends in education.  Emphasis is placed upon topics related to curriculum, instructional strategies, and evaluation.

courseTitle: Independent Study
courseDescription: Hours to be arranged. Allows the student to engage in independent study of issues and trends in education. Emphasis is placed upon topics related to curriculum, instructional strategies, and evaluation.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of educational issues and trends

courseTitle: Developing Instructional Strategies PreK-6: Language Arts
courseDescription: Following a theory into practice philosophy, students explore, develop, and use instructional strategies, materials, technologies, and activities to promote children's development of attitudes, behaviors, and concepts in language arts in grades PreK-6 in support of NCTE national instructional standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and applying NCTE national instructional standards
Understanding and applying Virginia Standards of Learning
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Promoting children's development of attitudes and behaviors
Engaging students in language arts activities
Interacting effectively with children in grades PreK-6
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting instructional strategies to individual student needs
Evaluating effectiveness of instructional materials and activities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and implementing language arts activities
Coordinating instructional strategies with national and state standards
Leading language arts instruction in a classroom setting

courseTitle: Developing Instructional Strategies PreK-6: Social Studies
courseDescription: Following a theory into practice philosophy, students explore, develop, and use instructional strategies, materials, technologies, and activities to promote children's development of attitudes, behaviors, and concepts in social studies in grades PreK-6 in support of NCSS national instructional standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning.
Technical and Digital Skills: Adoption of materials for teaching social studies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Promoting children's concepts in social studies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Linking theory with practice in education
Understanding and applying NCSS national instructional standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading educational activities for PreK-6 grades

courseTitle: Developing Instructional Strategies for Teaching in the Middle/High School: English
courseDescription: Following a theory/research-into-practice philosophy, students explore, develop, and use instructional strategies, materials, technologies, and activities to promote the development of attitudes, behaviors, and concepts in English, grades 6-12, informed by national instructional standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning; 35 hours of teaching practicum required.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Promoting development of attitudes and behaviors in English
Conveying complex English concepts to students grades 6-12
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching strategies to meet national and state standards
Evaluating effectiveness of instructional materials and technologies

courseTitle: Developing Instructional Strategies for Teaching in Middle/High School: Math and Science
courseDescription: This science and mathematics course will provide methods for teaching diverse learners through culturally sustaining pedagogy, inquiry-oriented, and problem solving strategies using technology and engineering design principles. Students in this course take a required practicum (35 hours) in a secondary science or mathematics classroom to complete assigned content-focused activities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of scientific and mathematical concepts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Practical teaching in a secondary classroom environment
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving strategies in science and math education
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and leading content-focused classroom activities

courseTitle: Developing Instructional Strategies for Teaching in the Middle/High School: Social Studies
courseDescription: Following a theory/research-into-practice philosophy, students explore, develop, and use instructional strategies, materials, technologies, and activities to promote the development of attitudes, behaviors, and concepts in social studies, grades 6-12, informed by national instructional standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning; 35 hours of teaching practicum required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Creating educational materials using digital tools
Adapting national instructional standards to digital teaching platforms
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Promoting development of attitudes and behaviors in students
Practicing effective teaching methods in a classroom setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching methods to cater to different learning styles
Incorporating Virginia Standards of Learning into teaching plans
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing educational materials and activities effectively

courseTitle: Language Acquisition and Reading for Students with Diverse Learning Needs
courseDescription: This course provides an overview of normal language development and language disorders which impact the acquisition of language based curriculum skills such as listening, speaking, reading, and written expression.  Emphasis is on instructional techniques to assist students with diverse learning needs to achieve reading and comprehension skills.  Effective reading strategies and curricula for individuals with disabilities will also be reviewed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Adapting reading strategies for individuals with disabilities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating effectively with students with diverse learning needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing solutions for language acquisition challenges
Analyzing the effectiveness of reading strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing diverse learning needs in a classroom
Leading and implementing an inclusive reading curriculum

courseTitle: Foundations and Contemporary Issues in Early Childhood Education
courseDescription: This course addresses current issues related to children and families in early childhood settings.  Contemporary research on pedagogical and formative assessment practices related to the education of young children will be discussed through critical exploration. This course will also have an associated 40 hour practicum (20 hours in an infant or toddler classroom and 20 hours in a preschool age classroom).
Technical and Digital Skills: Pedagogical techniques for early childhood education
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with children and families
Interacting with infants, toddlers, preschool aged children
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of current issues related to children and families
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a classroom for infants, toddlers and preschool children

courseTitle: Integrating Instruction Across the Curriculum PreK-6
courseDescription: Following a theory into practice philosophy and building on the instructional strategies for specific disciplines, students explore, develop, and use advanced instructional materials, technologies, and activities to promote interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary instruction across the curriculum in grades PreK-6 in support of national standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning. The field experience component (40 hours) includes participation in prek-3 and 4th-6th grade classrooms in an accredited public or non-public school, per program requirement.
Technical and Digital Skills: Promotion of interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary instruction using digital tools
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with prek-3 and 4th-6th grade students
Collaboration with other teachers and school staff
Presentation of complex concepts in a child-friendly manner
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adaptation of instructional strategies for different disciplines
Analysis and application of national standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning
Evaluation and improvement of instructional materials and activities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of instruction across different disciplines
Supervision and guidance during field experience component
Leadership in promoting national standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning

courseTitle: Classroom Management and Practice PreK-3; PreK-6
courseDescription: Course prepares prospective PreK-3 and PreK-6 teachers to provide instruction and management addressing the intellectual, physical, emotional and social needs of PreK-6 learners founded in empirically based practice.  The field based component (70 hours) includes participation in PreK-3 and 4th-6th grade classrooms in an accredited public or non-public school.  Students in the Prek-3 program are required to complete 35 hours in the Children's Learning and Research Center. Attendance at seminars and debriefing sessions is required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of empirically based teaching practices
Understanding and addressing diverse learning needs
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Active participation in seminars and debriefing sessions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Addressing intellectual, physical, emotional and social needs of PreK-6 learners
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing learning activities for PreK-6 learners
Managing time effectively in a classroom setting

courseTitle: Multicultural Young Adult Literature in Schools
courseDescription: This course will explore the reading and teaching of diverse young adult literature. Topics addressed include ideas about adolescents and their learning practices; characteristics of young adult literature and literary criticism; analysis of texts from a range of young adult genres; methods for teaching young adult literature; and lesson and unit design.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of texts from diverse young adult genres
Methods for teaching young adult literature
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and relating to adolescents and their learning practices
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical reading of diverse young adult literature
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and managing diverse literature materials

courseTitle: Seminar in Teacher Education
courseDescription: This course explores issues, problems, concerns, and processes related to teaching and entering the profession of teaching.  Passing score on Elementary Education Multiple Subjects Assessment in licensure content area, passing scores on the Virginia Communication and Literacy Assessment (VCLA), and where appropriate passing scores on Reading for Virginia Educators are required to pass this course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Passing Elementary Education Multiple Subjects Assessment
Understanding of Virginia Communication and Literacy Assessment (VCLA)
Knowledge on Reading for Virginia Educators

courseTitle: Student Teaching for Special Endorsement
courseDescription: Internship in school.  Available for pass/fail grading only.

courseTitle: Topics in Education
courseDescription: Explores contemporary problems and trends in education.  Emphasis is placed upon topics related to curriculum, instructional strategies, and evaluation.

courseTitle: Topics in Education
courseDescription: Cannot be applied to a Master of Science in Education degree in the Department of Teaching and Learning.  Explores contemporary problems and trends in education.  Emphasis is placed upon topics related to curriculum, instructional strategies, and evaluation.

courseTitle: Independent Study
courseDescription: Hours to be arranged. Allows the student to engage in independent study of issues and trends in education. Emphasis is placed upon topics related to curriculum, instructional strategies, and evaluation.

courseTitle: Foundations of Education and Instructional Assessment
courseDescription: Provides students with an understanding of historical, philosophical, economic, and sociological issues in American education, their effect on student achievement, and the impact of social change on existing institutions.  Includes the development of instruction based on assessment data including the use, construction, interpretation, and analysis of valid assessments.  A 30-hour observation/participation experience is required in an appropriate prek-6, 6-8, or 6-12 grade level.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with students of various age groups
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of various factors on student achievement
Developing instruction based on assessment data
Understanding and analyzing social changes and their effects on education institutions

courseTitle: Arts in Education
courseDescription: This course is designed to provide students with a range of approaches for thinking about the arts in education, with specific emphasis on the visual arts. It assumes that life in the 21st century calls for competencies that are critical, flexible, collaborative, and relational and forwards artistic thinking as complementary to this need. In addition to course readings that explore cognitive, developmental, cultural, and social dimensions of art and learning, students will be asked to participate in activities associated with making and viewing art, as well as consider implications for designing K-12 curriculum.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Cultural and social dimensions of art communication
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Designing and implementing art-based learning activities

courseTitle: Teaching in the Middle School
courseDescription: Focusing on middle school teaching, this course examines the organization, curriculum, instructional strategies, classroom management techniques, and teaching methods for working with young adolescents.  Also covered are middle school guidance, exploratories, scheduling, and parent-school relations.  A 30-hour practicum in a middle school is required.

courseTitle: Digital Age Teaching and Learning
courseDescription: In this class, contemporary digital tools and Internet resources are used to develop instructional plans and contribute to teaching techniques. The course is designed with three components: effectively integrating technology into the delivery of the curriculum, evidence-based good teaching practices utilizing technology that spans across grades and subject levels, and the technologies that support those practices. Upon completion of this course students should be able to pass, or apply for exemption from their school district's TSIP exam.
Technical and Digital Skills: Using digital tools and Internet resources for teaching
Applying evidence-based teaching practices utilizing technology
Understanding technologies that support teaching practices
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effectively communicating instruction through digital platforms
Collaborating with peers to integrate technology into teaching practices
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying appropriate technology for specific curriculum needs
Analyzing the effectiveness of technology in teaching practices
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and organizing instructional plans using technology
Leading the integration of technology into teaching

courseTitle: Assessment and Evaluation in PK-12 Schools
courseDescription: This course will prepare teachers for the appropriate use of formative and summative assessment and evaluation principles in support of students' learning and development. Students will learn to analyze assessment data to evaluate reliability and validity, interpret student performance, and make instructional decisions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of formative and summative assessment principles
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Providing constructive feedback based on assessment results
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of assessment reliability and validity
Instructional decision-making based on student performance

courseTitle: Education and Public Policy
courseDescription: This course is designed to provide students with an understanding of the political nature of education and its implications for teaching and learning. Students will be expected to critically consider the development and implementation of formal policies designed to improve education in U.S. schools. To do so, students will consider historical and contemporary trends in educational theory and research to situate current policies and practices in our nation’s schools, with a clear focus on understanding the range and scope of policy dilemmas in the public pre-K–12 sector of education.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding historical and contemporary trends in education
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding the scope of policy dilemmas in education

courseTitle: Foundations and History of Education
courseDescription: This seminar explores foundational ideas of democratic education. While focusing on the contexts and conditions of contemporary education, it traces the roots of educational theory and philosophy from the formation of the common school to the policy reforms of the 21st century. This look at the present through the past provides insight into the interactions between social, economic, political, ideological, and environmental factors and its impact on the purposes of education, school curriculum and ideas of measurement and evaluation. Students will be expected to consider the implications of/for democratic education, historically and presently, as it relates to issues of race, class, gender, and multiculturalism.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of educational theories and policies
Analysis of social, economic, political, ideological, and environmental factors in education

courseTitle: Introduction to the Contemporary Student
courseDescription: The course is designed to explore contemporary youth as learners with multiple dimensions of identity, including cultural and linguistic diversity. Topics explored include physical, social, emotional, language and conceptual development; digital and print production and consumption; and the selection, development, and use of appropriate curricula, methodologies, and materials for the contemporary student. The course includes a practicum experience (20 hours) as well.
Technical and Digital Skills: Selection and development of appropriate curricula and materials
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Facilitation of social and emotional development
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and adapting to multiple dimensions of student identity
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and implementing appropriate curricula and methodologies

courseTitle: Teaching Language, Culture, and Society in Elementary Education
courseDescription: This course will provide methods for teaching diverse learners through culturally sustaining pedagogy, effective methods for designing instructional strategies and materials for teaching social studies and language arts in the elementary grades. Students in this course take a corequisite practicum (40 hours) in elementary classrooms to complete assigned activities designed to further practical development.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching methods for diverse learners

courseTitle: Classroom Management, Discipline, and Practice
courseDescription: This course prepares prospective PreK-3 and PreK-6 teachers to provide instruction and management addressing the intellectual, physical, emotional and social needs of PreK-6 learners founded in empirically based practice. The field based component (40 hours) includes participation in PreK-3 and 4th-6th grade classrooms in an accredited public or non-public school setting.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of empirically based teaching practices
Adapting instruction to different age groups
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Addressing intellectual, physical, emotional, and social needs of learners
Communicating effectively in a PreK-6 learning environment
Building relationships in an accredited public or non-public school setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in classroom management and discipline

courseTitle: Middle Level Philosophy, School Organization and the Young Adolescent
courseDescription: This course focuses on theories and principles of adolescent development and learning in family, school, and community contexts.  Candidates examine adolescents from biological, psychological, cognitive, and social perspectives. This includes how adolescents learn and what motivates them to learn, and how schools contribute to adolescents’ growth by teaching in ways that “fit” their developmental and cultural needs.
Technical and Digital Skills: Principles of cognitive, biological, and social learning
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Adapting communication to fit developmental and cultural needs
Effectively engaging with adolescents in family, school, and community contexts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing adolescent motivation and learning methods
Critical evaluation of teaching methods and their impact on adolescent growth
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing educational environments to fit adolescents' needs
Leadership in fostering developmental and cultural inclusivity in schools

courseTitle: Develop and Enhancing Literacy with Culturally and Linguistically Diverse Learner Across Content Areas
courseDescription: This course focuses on the development and implementation of strategies that will accommodate how language and cultural differences affect communication and learning; knowledge of the impact of language-based curriculum skills such as listening, speaking, reading, and writing; instructional techniques needed to assist individuals identified as culturally, linguistically, and academically diverse in achieving reading and comprehension skills; comprehension strategies; and an understanding of reading across the disciplines.
Technical and Digital Skills: Development and implementation of language and cultural learning strategies
Adapting curriculum for diverse linguistic backgrounds
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Teaching listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills
Effective communication with linguistically diverse individuals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and application of reading across disciplines

courseTitle: Classroom Based Inquiry
courseDescription: This course is designed to integrate the research on effective teaching and learning with theory and practice through the lens of democratic education. As an introductory survey course, the focus will be on developing the competencies related to the critical consumption of research literature in order to further the teacher candidates’ understanding of the physical, social, emotional, speech and language and intellectual development of children.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Applying teaching and learning theories in practice
Leadership in a democratic education context

courseTitle: Multicultural Education
courseDescription: This course will explore critical multicultural education situated within culturally sustaining pedagogical practices to explore issues related to race, ethnicity, class, gender, sexuality, religion, power, and language use; however, this course is not about a celebration of difference, but is designed to enable students to investigate how socially constructed categories such as social class, race, gender, sexual orientation, and disability are used to privilege some and marginalize others.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication across different social classes, races, genders, sexual orientations, and disabilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of cultural categories and social constructs
Analysis of power dynamics in multicultural contexts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and leading discussions on sensitive multicultural issues

courseTitle: Middle Level Instruction and Assessment
courseDescription: This course will provide opportunities to examine the theoretical and practical applications of data-driven decision making, assessments, and curriculum planning for middle level educators. Students will consider adolescent development as well as student behaviors to analyze standards and effectively plan instruction and assessment. Further, students will apply principles of culturally sustaining pedagogy to middle school instruction and assessment planning and practices.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpreting and responding to student behaviors
Communicating effectively with middle school students
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Planning instruction based on data analysis
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementing culturally sustaining pedagogy in middle school settings

courseTitle: Problems in Education
courseDescription: Provides practice in the use of quantitative or qualitative techniques, including analytical processes, in solving problems in education. Pass/Fail grading only.

courseTitle: Researching Teaching in Elementary and Secondary Grades
courseDescription: In this course, students will learn the processes of reflective inquiry and conduct informal inquiries of the teaching and learning dynamic in preK-12 school settings. Activities include explorations of professional biography school and classroom culture and practice, student demographics, curriculum, and other critical components of teaching and learning.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with diverse student populations
Professional interaction in a school setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Informal investigation of teaching and learning dynamics
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing explorations of professional biography school
Management of critical components of teaching and learning

courseTitle: Seminar in Education
courseDescription: Hours to be arranged.  Explores in depth a variety of current topics, trends and concerns in K-12 education.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of digital tools for research
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of educational trends and issues
Evaluating the effectiveness of K-12 systems

courseTitle: The Management of Learning and Instruction
courseDescription: This course explores classroom and behavior management techniques including teacher-student relationships, rules and procedures, and disciplinary interventions. Emphasis is placed on building a diverse repertoire of approaches to classroom management at the individual and classroom level. Candidates will develop a classroom management plan that includes techniques for engaging families.
Technical and Digital Skills: Development of a classroom management plan
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adaptation of diverse approaches to classroom management
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Establishment and enforcement of rules and procedures
Implementation of a classroom management plan

courseTitle: Introduction to the Contemporary Student
courseDescription: The course is designed to be an exploration of contemporary youth as learners situated in/by many identities, including those aspects of self related to cultural and linguistic diversity. Among the subjects to be explored are: physical, social, emotional, language and conceptual development; digital and print production and consumption; and the selection, development, and use of appropriate curricula, methodologies, and materials for the contemporary student.
Technical and Digital Skills: Selection of appropriate curricula and methodologies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Social and emotional engagement with youth
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading diverse and inclusive learning environments

courseTitle: Classroom Based Inquiry
courseDescription: This course is designed to integrate the research on effective teaching and learning with theory and practice through the lens of democratic education. As an introductory survey course, the focus will be on developing the competencies related to the critical consumption of research literature in order to further the candidates’ understanding of the physical, social, emotional, speech and language and intellectual development of children. Diverse approaches based upon culturally responsive behavioral, cognitive, affective, social, and ecological theory and practice will be utilized in guiding the learning experience of the course.

courseTitle: Education and Public Policy
courseDescription: This course is designed to provide students with an understanding of the political nature of education and its implications for teaching and learning. Students will be expected to critically consider the development and implementation of formal policies designed to improve education in US schools. To do so, students will consider historical and contemporary trends in educational theory and research to situate current policies and practices in our nation’s schools, with a clear focus on understanding the range and scope of policy dilemmas in the public pre-K–12 sector of education.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Change management and leadership in education

courseTitle: Mathematics Specialists as Teacher Leaders
courseDescription: The critical characteristics and responsibilities of Mathematics Specialists as teacher leaders will be explored. Structuring professional learning for classroom teachers through peer coaching, mentoring, observations, conferencing and relational group learning will be explored for developing teacher leadership capacity.

courseTitle: Teaching Mathematics for All Using Culturally Responsive Approaches
courseDescription: Adapting the mathematics teaching and learning practices to accommodate diverse populations will be explored. The essential knowledge and understanding needed by mathematics specialists to support classroom teachers to effectively utilize culturally responsive pedagogies to differentiate instruction and support all learners.
Technical and Digital Skills: Differentiating instruction based on student needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting instruction to suit individual learner needs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading classroom teachers in implementing culturally responsive approaches

courseTitle: Participatory Action Research for Mathematics Specialists
courseDescription: Participatory Action Research is introduced to conduct community, school, or classroom-based research for improving mathematics learning and teaching.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of digital tools for research
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in classroom or community-based research

courseTitle: Practicum for Mathematics Specialists
courseDescription: This course requires candidates to complete a 150-hour practicum that is designed to provide opportunities and learning experiences to refine and reinforce mathematical and leadership skills, understandings, and dispositions for optimal performance as a Mathematics Specialist.

courseTitle: Mathematical Assessment for Data Driven Decisions
courseDescription: Selected key differences between assessment for and of learning will be examined. Students will design quality assessment systems that provide numerical and descriptive information about student learning and explore ways to use these data to drive instructional decisions for improved learning.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of numerical and descriptive data

courseTitle: Internship/Student Teaching and Seminar
courseDescription: Five days per week for 14 weeks.  Available for pass/fail grading only.   Provides practice in teaching in grades 6-8 and in analyzing teaching approaches and behaviors.  Examines instructional problems and concerns.

courseTitle: Internship/Student Teaching and Seminar in PreK-3
courseDescription: This course provides practice in teaching in grades PK-3 and in analyzing teaching approaches and behaviors. It examines instructional problems and concerns. Each semester the candidate must maintain continuance and a 3.0 GPA to enroll in each teacher candidate internship semester for a total of 9 semester credit hours. Available for pass/fail grading only.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment and improvement of teaching methods

courseTitle: Internship/Student Teaching and Seminar
courseDescription: Five days per week for 14 weeks.  Available for pass/fail grading only.   Provides practice in teaching in grades PK-6 and in analyzing teaching approaches and behaviors. Examines instructional problems and concerns.

courseTitle: Internship/Student Teaching and Seminar
courseDescription: Five days per week for 6-14 weeks.  Available for pass/fail grading only.  Provides practice in teaching and in analyzing teaching approaches and behaviors. Examines instructional problems and concerns.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a classroom setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and addressing of instructional problems

courseTitle: Practitioner Inquiry in Elementary and Secondary Grades
courseDescription: In this course, students will explore research methods and forms of data collection and analysis associated with practitioner inquiry, including self-study and action research. Students will be required to design a research proposal using practitioner inquiry research methods.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing results from self-studies and action research
Designing and refining research proposals based on analysis
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing data from self-studies and action research
